Sequences and Series

2.2 The Limit of a Sequence

Notes

Definition: A sequence is a function whose domain is N\NN.

  • This is really just an ordered list where the function f(n)f(n)f(n) indexes the list at the nnnth entry.

Definition (Convergence of a Sequence) A sequence (an)(a_n)(an​) converges to a real number aaa if ∀ϵ>0,∃N∈N\forall \epsilon > 0, \exists N \in \N∀ϵ>0,∃N∈N s.t. if n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, then ∣a−an∣<ϵ|a - a_n| < \epsilon∣a−an​∣<ϵ.

Definition: Given a∈Ra \in \Ra∈R and ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, the set

Vϵ(a)={x∈R∣(∣x−a∣<ϵ}V_\epsilon(a) = \{x \in \R | (|x - a| < \epsilon\}Vϵ​(a)={x∈R∣(∣x−a∣<ϵ}

is the ϵ\epsilonϵ-neighborhood of aaa

Definition (Convergence of a sequence: Topological Version): A sequence (an)(a_n)(an​) converges to aaa if, given any ϵ\epsilonϵ-neighborhood Vϵ(a)V_\epsilon(a)Vϵ​(a) of aaa, ∃N∈N\exists N \in \N∃N∈N such that for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, an∈Vϵ(a)a_n \in V_\epsilon(a)an​∈Vϵ​(a).

Example: Consider (an)(a_n)(an​), where an=1na_n = \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}an​=n​1​. Prove that lim⁡(an)=0\lim (a_n) = 0lim(an​)=0 Proof: Consider arbitrary ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Note that

∣an−a∣=∣an−0∣=∣an∣=∣1n∣=1n |a_n - a| = |a_n - 0| = |a_n| = |\frac{1}{\sqrt{n}}| = \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} ∣an​−a∣=∣an​−0∣=∣an​∣=∣n​1​∣=n​1​

Choose N>1ϵ2N > \frac{1}{\epsilon^2}N>ϵ21​. Note that

n≥N>1ϵ2⇒1n≤1N<ϵ2⇒1n≤1N<ϵ n \geq N > \frac{1}{\epsilon^2} \Rightarrow \frac{1}{n} \leq \frac{1}{N} < \epsilon^2 \Rightarrow \frac{1}{\sqrt{n}} \leq \frac{1}{\sqrt{N}} < \epsilon n≥N>ϵ21​⇒n1​≤N1​<ϵ2⇒n​1​≤N​1​<ϵ

Since an=∣an−0∣a_n = |a_n - 0|an​=∣an​−0∣, then

∣an−0∣<ϵ |a_n - 0| < \epsilon ∣an​−0∣<ϵ

■\blacksquare■

Example: Show that

lim⁡(n+1n)=1 \lim \Big( \frac{n+1}{n}\Big) = 1lim(nn+1​)=1

Pre-proof: Consider

∣n+1n−1∣<ϵ. \Big| \frac{n+1}{n} - 1 \Big| < \epsilon .∣∣∣∣​nn+1​−1∣∣∣∣​<ϵ.

=1n. =\frac{1}{n} .=n1​.

Thus

∣n+1n−1∣=1n<ϵ. \Big| \frac{n+1}{n} - 1 \Big| = \frac{1}{n} < \epsilon .∣∣∣∣​nn+1​−1∣∣∣∣​=n1​<ϵ.

⇒n>1ϵ \Rightarrow n > \frac{1}{\epsilon} ⇒n>ϵ1​

Proof: Choose N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that N>1ϵN > \frac{1}{\epsilon}N>ϵ1​. Then for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N this means

n≥N>1ϵ n \geq N > \frac{1}{\epsilon} n≥N>ϵ1​

⇒1n≤1N<ϵ \Rightarrow \frac{1}{n} \leq \frac{1}{N} < \epsilon ⇒n1​≤N1​<ϵ

⇒∣n+1n−1∣<ϵ \Rightarrow \Big| \frac{n+1}{n} - 1 \Big| < \epsilon ⇒∣∣∣∣​nn+1​−1∣∣∣∣​<ϵ

My Corollary 1: Consider sequence (an)(a_n)(an​). (an)(a_n)(an​) converges to aaa if and only if ∣an−a∣→0|a_n - a| \rightarrow 0∣an​−a∣→0. Proof:

  1. (⇒\Rightarrow⇒): We know (an)→a(a_n) \rightarrow a(an​)→a. Thus for arbitrary ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exists N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. ∀n≥N\forall n \geq N∀n≥N,

∣an−a∣<ϵ. |a_n - a| < \epsilon . ∣an​−a∣<ϵ.

Denote the sequence ∣an−a∣=dn|a_n - a| = d_n∣an​−a∣=dn​. Consider arbitrary ϵ′>0\epsilon' > 0ϵ′>0. Note that

∣dn−0∣=dn. |d_n - 0| = d_n .∣dn​−0∣=dn​.

Thus, to show lim⁡dn=0\lim d_n = 0limdn​=0, we simply show that ∃N′∈N\exists N' \in \N∃N′∈N s.t. ∀n≥N′\forall n \geq N'∀n≥N′,

dn<ϵ′. d_n < \epsilon' .dn​<ϵ′.

Choose N′=NN' = NN′=N, where ∀n≥N\forall n \geq N∀n≥N, ∣an−a∣<ϵ′|a_n - a| < \epsilon'∣an​−a∣<ϵ′. Therefore, ∣an−a∣=dn<ϵ′|a_n - a| = d_n < \epsilon'∣an​−a∣=dn​<ϵ′

  1. (⇐\Leftarrow⇐): We know (dn=∣an−a∣)→0(d_n = |a_n - a|) \rightarrow 0(dn​=∣an​−a∣)→0. Thus, for arbitrary ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exists N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. ∀n≥N\forall n \geq N∀n≥N,

The above statement shows, for the same NNN, by the equality between ∣an−a∣=dn|a_n - a| = d_n∣an​−a∣=dn​,

∣an−a∣<ϵ. |a_n - a| < \epsilon .∣an​−a∣<ϵ.

Definition: A sequence that does not converge is said to diverge.

Exercises

2.1.b: Prove that lim⁡3n+12n+5=32\lim \frac{3n + 1}{2n + 5} = \frac{3}{2}lim2n+53n+1​=23​.

Proof: First consider the inequality we want to show:

∣3n+12n+5−32∣<ϵ |\frac{3n + 1}{2n + 5} - \frac{3}{2} | < \epsilon∣2n+53n+1​−23​∣<ϵ

Note that

∣3n+12n+5−32∣=∣6n+24n+10−6n+154n+10∣ |\frac{3n + 1}{2n + 5} - \frac{3}{2} | = |\frac{6n + 2}{4n + 10} - \frac{6n + 15}{4n + 10} |∣2n+53n+1​−23​∣=∣4n+106n+2​−4n+106n+15​∣

=∣−134n+10∣=134n+10 = |\frac{-13}{4n + 10} | = \frac{13}{4n + 10} =∣4n+10−13​∣=4n+1013​

So now solving for the relationship between nnn and ϵ\epsilonϵ in terms of ϵ\epsilonϵ.

134n+10<ϵ⇒134ϵ−52<n \frac{13}{4n + 10} < \epsilon \Rightarrow \frac{13}{4\epsilon} - \frac{5}{2} < n 4n+1013​<ϵ⇒4ϵ13​−25​<n

Thus we choose N>134ϵ−52N > \frac{13}{4\epsilon} - \frac{5}{2}N>4ϵ13​−25​. As n≥N⇒n>134ϵ−52n \geq N \Rightarrow n > \frac{13}{4\epsilon} - \frac{5}{2}n≥N⇒n>4ϵ13​−25​, by the above algebra, we can conclude

∣3n+12n+5−32∣<ϵ |\frac{3n + 1}{2n + 5} - \frac{3}{2} | < \epsilon∣2n+53n+1​−23​∣<ϵ

■\blacksquare■

2.2: What happens if we reverse the order of the quantifiers in our definition of convergence: Definition: A sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) verconges to xxx if $ \exists \epsilon > 0$ such that ∀N∈N\forall N \in \N∀N∈N it is true that n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N implies ∣xn−x∣<ϵ|x_n -x| < \epsilon∣xn​−x∣<ϵ Give an example of a vercongent sequence that is divergent. What exactly is being described.

Solution: When we reverse the order of the quantifiers, our definition states we only need to find one ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 such that ∣xn−x∣<ϵ|x_n - x| < \epsilon∣xn​−x∣<ϵ for all elements of the sequence (every n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N is ≥\geq≥ some N∈NN \in \NN∈N). Thus our entire sequence is bounded by some ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Note that if at some N∈NN \in \NN∈N, our subsequence becomes vercongent, we can change the ϵ\epsilonϵ to max⁡(ϵ,∣x1−x∣,…,∣xN−1−x∣)\max (\epsilon, |x_1-x|, \dots, |x_{N-1}-x|)max(ϵ,∣x1​−x∣,…,∣xN−1​−x∣) and thus it will remain vercongent. So when a sequence is vercongent, it's distance to xxx is bounded. A diverging sequence that is vercongent is

(1,−1,1,−1,… ) (1, -1, 1, -1, \dots) (1,−1,1,−1,…)

It verconges to 000 with ϵ=2\epsilon = 2ϵ=2.

2.4: Argue that the sequence

1,0,1,0,0,1,0,0,0,1,(4 zeros),1,… 1, 0, 1, 0, 0, 1, 0, 0, 0, 1, \text{(4 zeros)}, 1, \dots 1,0,1,0,0,1,0,0,0,1,(4 zeros),1,…

does not converge to zero. For what values of ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 does there exists a response NNN and for which is there no suitable response?

Proof: Consider ϵ=12\epsilon = \frac{1}{2}ϵ=21​. As the number of zeros between two 1's grows by one after each 1 and there are a finite number of 1's in the first NNN elements, at any N∈NN \in \NN∈N, there are a finite number of 0's before the first 1 after NNN. Thus ∃n≥N\exists n \geq N∃n≥N such that

∣an−0∣=∣an∣>ϵ=12 |a_n - 0 | = |a_n| > \epsilon = \frac{1}{2} ∣an​−0∣=∣an​∣>ϵ=21​

namely where an=1a_n = 1an​=1. ■\blacksquare■ For any ϵ>1\epsilon > 1ϵ>1, all elements of the sequence are within ϵ\epsilonϵ distance of 000.

2.5: Let [[x]][[x]][[x]] be the greatest integer less than or equal to xxx. For example, [[π]]=3[[\pi]] = 3[[π]]=3 and [[3]]=3[[3]] = 3[[3]]=3. Find lim⁡an\lim a_nliman​ and supply proofs for each conclusion if

(a) an=[[1/n]]a_n = [[1/n]]an​=[[1/n]]

Proof: We will show that lim⁡an=1\lim a_n = 1liman​=1. First consider the inequality for ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0:

∣[[1/n]]−1∣<ϵ |[[1/n]] - 1| < \epsilon ∣[[1/n]]−1∣<ϵ

Note that as 1/n>01/n > 01/n>0, but can be arbitrarily small for some large nnn, [[1/n]]=1[[1/n]] = 1[[1/n]]=1 for n≥1n \geq 1n≥1. Thus, in actuality, the sequence

an=[[1/n]] a_n = [[1/n]] an​=[[1/n]]

is just an infinite sequence of 1's. Thus, no matter which ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 we choose, N=1N = 1N=1 will suffice as for any n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N:

∣[[1/n]]−1∣=∣1−1∣=0<ϵ. |[[1/n]] - 1| = |1 - 1| = 0 < \epsilon .∣[[1/n]]−1∣=∣1−1∣=0<ϵ.

■\blacksquare■

(b) an=[[(10+n)/2n]]a_n = [[(10 + n)/2n]]an​=[[(10+n)/2n]]

Proof: We will show that lim⁡an=1\lim a_n = 1liman​=1. First note that

[[(10+n)/2n]]=[[5/n+1/2]]. [[(10 + n)/2n]] = [[5/n + 1/2]] .[[(10+n)/2n]]=[[5/n+1/2]].

Similarly to part (a), as 5/n>05/n > 05/n>0 for n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, we see that

5/n+1/2>1/2 5/n + 1/2 > 1/2 5/n+1/2>1/2

However, for n≥10n \geq 10n≥10 we have

1/2<5/n+1/2≤1. 1/2 < 5/n + 1/2 \leq 1 .1/2<5/n+1/2≤1.

Thus for all n≥10n \geq 10n≥10, [[5/n+1/2]]=1[[5/n + 1/2]] = 1[[5/n+1/2]]=1. Thus N=10N = 10N=10 is a suitable response for all ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0.

Reflecting on the inverse relationship between the size of ϵ\epsilonϵ and the size of NNN, in this case, there is an NNN that satisfies all ϵ\epsilonϵ since the series both repeat the same element after some N∈NN \in \NN∈N.

2.3 The Algebraic and Order Limit Theorems

Definition 2.3.1: A sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​) is bounded if there exists a number M>0M > 0M>0 such that ∣xn∣≤M|x_n| \leq M∣xn​∣≤M for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.

  • Note that if a subseqeuence excluding the first nnn elements is bounded by MMM, then the whole sequence is bounded. We can take the bound to be max⁡(∣x1∣,…,∣xn∣,M)\max (|x_1|,\dots, |x_n|, M)max(∣x1​∣,…,∣xn​∣,M).

Theorem 2.3.2: Every convergent sequence is bounded.

Proof: Name our convergent sequence (xn)(x_n)(xn​). By definition of convergence, ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exists N \in \N∃N∈N such that if n>Nn > Nn>N then ∣xn−x∣<ϵ|x_n - x| < \epsilon∣xn​−x∣<ϵ for some x∈Rx \in \Rx∈R. Consider ϵ=1\epsilon = 1ϵ=1. Let N∈NN \in \NN∈N be such that if n>Nn > Nn>N, ∣xn−x∣<1|x_n - x| < 1∣xn​−x∣<1. Note that

∣xn−x∣<1|x_n - x| < 1∣xn​−x∣<1

⇒∣xn−x∣+∣x∣<1+∣x∣\Rightarrow |x_n - x| + |x| < 1 + |x|⇒∣xn​−x∣+∣x∣<1+∣x∣

⇒∣xn−x+x∣<1+∣x∣ (by triangle inequality) \Rightarrow |x_n - x + x| < 1 + |x| \text{ (by triangle inequality) }⇒∣xn​−x+x∣<1+∣x∣ (by triangle inequality) 

⇒∣xn∣<1+∣x∣\Rightarrow |x_n| < 1 + |x|⇒∣xn​∣<1+∣x∣

Now consider

M=max⁡(∣x1∣,…,∣xN∣,1+∣x∣) M = \max (|x_1|, \dots, |x_N|, 1 + |x|) M=max(∣x1​∣,…,∣xN​∣,1+∣x∣)

By construction, M≥xiM \geq x_iM≥xi​ for all i∈Ni \in \Ni∈N. ■\blacksquare■

The below theorem shows that, given sequences and the fact that their individual limits exist, we can compute the limit of their algebraic compbinations intuitively.

Theorem 2.3.3 (Algebraic Limit Theorem): Let lim⁡an=a\lim a_n = aliman​=a and lim⁡bn=b\lim b_n = blimbn​=b. Then,

  1. lim⁡(can)=ca\lim (ca_n) = calim(can​)=ca, ∀c∈R\forall c \in \R∀c∈R
  2. lim⁡(an+bn)=a+b\lim (a_n + b_n) = a + blim(an​+bn​)=a+b
  3. lim⁡(anbn)=ab\lim(a_nb_n) = ablim(an​bn​)=ab
  4. lim⁡(an/bn)=a/b\lim(a_n / b_n) = a / blim(an​/bn​)=a/b

Note: Proofs for (3) and (4) on my notes are a little more complicated than in Abbot. See book for simpler proofs.

⇒∣anb−ab∣+∣abn−ab∣+∣(an−a)bn−(an−a)b∣<ϵ′\Rightarrow |a_nb - ab| + |ab_n - ab| + |(a_n - a)b_n - (a_n - a)b| < \epsilon'⇒∣an​b−ab∣+∣abn​−ab∣+∣(an​−a)bn​−(an​−a)b∣<ϵ′

⇒∣anbn+anb−anb+abn−abn−ab−ab+ab∣<ϵ′\Rightarrow |a_nb_n + a_nb - a_nb + ab_n - ab_n - ab - ab + ab| < \epsilon'⇒∣an​bn​+an​b−an​b+abn​−abn​−ab−ab+ab∣<ϵ′

⇒∣anbn−ab∣<ϵ′\Rightarrow |a_nb_n - ab| < \epsilon'⇒∣an​bn​−ab∣<ϵ′

Thus for n>Nn > Nn>N, anbn∈(ab−ϵ′,ab+ϵ′)a_nb_n \in (ab - \epsilon', ab + \epsilon')an​bn​∈(ab−ϵ′,ab+ϵ′). By definition of convergence, (anbn)→ab(a_nb_n) \rightarrow ab(an​bn​)→ab. ■\blacksquare■

  1. Proof: First we show that lim⁡1/bn→1/b\lim 1 / b_n \rightarrow 1 / blim1/bn​→1/b. We know that lim⁡(bn)=b\lim(b_n) = blim(bn​)=b. By definition of limit, this means that ∀ϵb>0\forall \epsilon_b > 0∀ϵb​>0, ∃Nb∈N\exists N_b \in \N∃Nb​∈N s.t. ∣bn−b∣<ϵb|b_n - b| < \epsilon_b∣bn​−b∣<ϵb​ for any n>Nbn > N_bn>Nb​. Now consider

∣1bn−1b∣ |\frac{1}{b_n} - \frac{1}{b}|∣bn​1​−b1​∣

=∣b−bnbnb∣= |\frac{b - b_n}{b_n b}|=∣bn​bb−bn​​∣

=1∣b∣∣bn∣∣b−bn∣(1)\tag{1} = \frac{1}{|b||b_n|}|b - b_n|=∣b∣∣bn​∣1​∣b−bn​∣(1)

Now choose ∣b∣>ϵb>0|b| > \epsilon_b > 0∣b∣>ϵb​>0 and let n>N∈Nn > N \in \Nn>N∈N s.t. ∣b−bn∣<ϵb|b - b_n| < \epsilon_b∣b−bn​∣<ϵb​. By definition of convergence, all bn∈(b−ϵb,b+ϵb)b_n \in (b - \epsilon_b, b + \epsilon_b)bn​∈(b−ϵb​,b+ϵb​) for n>Nn > Nn>N. This means we can construct the lower bound on ∣bn∣|b_n|∣bn​∣:

0<∣b∣−ϵb<∣bn∣<∣b∣+ϵb 0 < |b| - \epsilon_b < |b_n| < |b| + \epsilon_b0<∣b∣−ϵb​<∣bn​∣<∣b∣+ϵb​

Substituting into (1) we get

∣1bn−1b∣<1∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb)ϵb |\frac{1}{b_n} - \frac{1}{b}| < \frac{1}{|b|(|b| - \epsilon_b)}\epsilon_b∣bn​1​−b1​∣<∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb​)1​ϵb​

Now choose ϵ′>0\epsilon' > 0ϵ′>0 and ϵb\epsilon_bϵb​ s.t. ϵ′=1∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb)ϵb\epsilon' = \frac{1}{|b|(|b| - \epsilon_b)}\epsilon_bϵ′=∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb​)1​ϵb​. To verify that a valid ϵb>0\epsilon_b > 0ϵb​>0 exists for all choices of ϵ′\epsilon'ϵ′, we can solve the above equality for ϵb\epsilon_bϵb​

ϵ′=ϵb∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb) \epsilon' = \frac{\epsilon_b}{|b|(|b| - \epsilon_b)}ϵ′=∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb​)ϵb​​

⇒∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb)ϵ′=ϵb \Rightarrow |b|(|b| - \epsilon_b)\epsilon' = \epsilon_b⇒∣b∣(∣b∣−ϵb​)ϵ′=ϵb​

⇒∣b∣2ϵ′−∣b∣ϵbϵ′=ϵb \Rightarrow |b|^2\epsilon' - |b|\epsilon_b\epsilon' = \epsilon_b⇒∣b∣2ϵ′−∣b∣ϵb​ϵ′=ϵb​

⇒∣b∣2ϵ′=ϵb+∣b∣ϵbϵ′ \Rightarrow |b|^2\epsilon' = \epsilon_b + |b|\epsilon_b\epsilon'⇒∣b∣2ϵ′=ϵb​+∣b∣ϵb​ϵ′

⇒∣b∣2ϵ′=ϵb(1+∣b∣ϵ′) \Rightarrow |b|^2\epsilon' = \epsilon_b(1 + |b|\epsilon')⇒∣b∣2ϵ′=ϵb​(1+∣b∣ϵ′)

⇒∣b∣2ϵ′1+∣b∣ϵ′=ϵb \Rightarrow \frac{|b|^2\epsilon'}{1 + |b|\epsilon'} = \epsilon_b⇒1+∣b∣ϵ′∣b∣2ϵ′​=ϵb​

As all the terms on the left are positive, we're guaranteed to find an ϵb\epsilon_bϵb​ that works for any given ϵ′>0\epsilon' > 0ϵ′>0. Thus, for n>N∈Nn > N \in \Nn>N∈N such that:

∣bn−b∣<∣b∣2ϵ′1+∣b∣ϵ′|b_n - b| < \frac{|b|^2\epsilon'}{1 + |b|\epsilon'}∣bn​−b∣<1+∣b∣ϵ′∣b∣2ϵ′​

Our work above shows that

∣1bn−1b∣<ϵ′ |\frac{1}{b_n} - \frac{1}{b}| < \epsilon'∣bn​1​−b1​∣<ϵ′

and (1/bn)→1/b(1 / b_n) \rightarrow 1/b(1/bn​)→1/b. Now consider lim⁡an/bn=an∗1/bn\lim a_n / b_n = a_n * 1/b_nliman​/bn​=an​∗1/bn​. Using part (3) of the Algebraic Limit Theorem, we know (an/bn)→a/b(a_n / b_n) \rightarrow a/b(an​/bn​)→a/b. ■\blacksquare■

From here on out, I'll use the phrase

  1. For x(n)>0x(n) > 0x(n)>0 ∀n\forall n∀n: "x(n)x(n)x(n) can be made arbitrarily small" to mean that ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, x(n)<ϵx(n) < \epsilonx(n)<ϵ.
  2. For x(n)x(n)x(n): "x(n)x(n)x(n) can be made arbitrarily close to lll" to mean that ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, ∣x(n)−l∣<ϵ|x(n) - l| < \epsilon∣x(n)−l∣<ϵ.
  3. For x(n)x(n)x(n): "Proposition of x(n)x(n)x(n) is true for sufficiently large nnn" to mean that ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. for all n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, proposition of x(n)x(n)x(n) is true.

The below theorem shows that the limit behaves intuitively under non-strict orderings.

Theorem 2.3.4 (Order Limit Theorem): Assume lim⁡an=a\lim a_n = aliman​=a and lim⁡bn=b\lim b_n = blimbn​=b.

  1. If an≥0a_n \geq 0an​≥0 for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N then a≥0a \geq 0a≥0.
  2. If an≤bna_n \leq b_nan​≤bn​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, then a≤ba \leq ba≤b.
  3. If there exists c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R for which c≤bnc \leq b_nc≤bn​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, then c≤bc \leq bc≤b. Similarly, if an≤ca_n \leq can​≤c for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N.

  1. Proof: We know lim⁡an=a\lim a_n = aliman​=a, so ∣an−a∣|a_n - a|∣an​−a∣ can be arbitrarily small. Assume that a<0a < 0a<0. As ∣an−a∣|a_n - a|∣an​−a∣ can be arbitrarily small, choose ϵ=∣a∣2\epsilon = \frac{|a|}{2}ϵ=2∣a∣​. Thus for sufficiently large nnn,

an<a+∣a∣2=a2<0⇒⇐ a_n < a + \frac{|a|}{2} = \frac{a}{2} < 0 \Rightarrow\Leftarrowan​<a+2∣a∣​=2a​<0⇒⇐

■\blacksquare■

  1. Proof: We know lim⁡an=a\lim a_n = aliman​=a and lim⁡bn=b\lim b_n = blimbn​=b, so ∣an−a∣|a_n - a|∣an​−a∣ and ∣bn−b∣|b_n - b|∣bn​−b∣ can be arbitrarily small. We also know that an≤bna_n \leq b_nan​≤bn​. Note that

an≤bn⇒cn=bn−an≥0 a_n \leq b_n \Rightarrow c_n = b_n - a_n \geq 0 an​≤bn​⇒cn​=bn​−an​≥0

By the Algebraic Limit Theorem, we know that lim⁡(bn−an)=b−a\lim (b_n - a_n) = b - alim(bn​−an​)=b−a. By part (1) of the Order Limit Theorem, we know

b−a≥0⇒a≤bb - a \geq 0 \Rightarrow a \leq bb−a≥0⇒a≤b

■\blacksquare■

  1. We know lim⁡bn=b\lim b_n = blimbn​=b, so ∣bn−b∣|b_n - b|∣bn​−b∣ can be arbitrarily small. We know there exists c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R for which c≤bnc \leq b_nc≤bn​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. Note that,

c≤bn⇒bn−c≥0 c \leq b_n \Rightarrow b_n - c \geq 0 c≤bn​⇒bn​−c≥0

By the Algebraic Limit Theorem, we know

lim⁡(bn−c)=b−c \lim (b_n - c) = b - c lim(bn​−c)=b−c

(the above fact is clear when you note that a repeating sequence (cn=c)→c(c_n = c) \rightarrow c(cn​=c)→c because ∣cn−c∣=0<ϵ|c_n - c| = 0 < \epsilon∣cn​−c∣=0<ϵ). By part (1) of the Order Limit Theorem:

bn−c≥0⇒b−c≥0⇒b≥cb_n - c \geq 0 \Rightarrow b - c \geq 0 \Rightarrow b \geq c bn​−c≥0⇒b−c≥0⇒b≥c

Now examine (an)(a_n)(an​). We know lim⁡an=a\lim a_n = aliman​=a, so ∣an−a∣|a_n - a|∣an​−a∣ can be arbitrarily small. We know there exists c∈Rc \in \Rc∈R for which c≥anc \geq a_nc≥an​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. Note that,

c≥an⇒c−an≥0 c \geq a_n \Rightarrow c - a_n \geq 0 c≥an​⇒c−an​≥0

By the Algebraic Limit Theorem, we know

lim⁡(c−an)=c−a \lim (c - a_n) = c - a lim(c−an​)=c−a

c−an≥0⇒c−a≥0⇒c≥ac - a_n \geq 0 \Rightarrow c - a \geq 0 \Rightarrow c \geq ac−an​≥0⇒c−a≥0⇒c≥a

■\blacksquare■

Notes:

  • Proof (3) is basically an expansion of letting an=ca_n = can​=c or bn=cb_n = cbn​=c and applying (2)

  • Though the theorem takes as given the ordering is true for all elements of our sequences, it will also apply if the ordering assumption is satisfied after some N∈NN \in \NN∈N. That's because a sequence's limit is equal to that of a tail subsequence.

Train Exercises: 2.3.3, 2.3.5, 2.3.11

2.3.3 (Squeeze Theorem): Show that if xn≤yn≤znx_n \leq y_n \leq z_nxn​≤yn​≤zn​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N, and if lim⁡xn=lim⁡zn=l\lim x_n = \lim z_n = llimxn​=limzn​=l, then lim⁡yn=l\lim y_n = llimyn​=l as well.

Proof: We know that lim⁡xn=lim⁡zn=l\lim x_n = \lim z_n = llimxn​=limzn​=l. So for ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0 and sufficiently large n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N we have

∣xn−l∣<ϵ and ∣zn−l∣<ϵ |x_n - l| < \epsilon \text{ and } |z_n - l| < \epsilon∣xn​−l∣<ϵ and ∣zn​−l∣<ϵ

This means that

xn∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) x_n \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)xn​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

⇔l−ϵ<xn<l+ϵ \Leftrightarrow l - \epsilon < x_n < l + \epsilon ⇔l−ϵ<xn​<l+ϵ

and

zn∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) z_n \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)zn​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

⇔l−ϵ<zn<l+ϵ \Leftrightarrow l - \epsilon < z_n < l + \epsilon ⇔l−ϵ<zn​<l+ϵ

We also know that xn≤yn≤znx_n \leq y_n \leq z_nxn​≤yn​≤zn​ ∀n∈N\forall n \in \N∀n∈N, so for sufficiently large n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N we have

l−ϵ<xn≤yn≤zn<l+ϵ l - \epsilon < x_n \leq y_n \leq z_n < l + \epsilon l−ϵ<xn​≤yn​≤zn​<l+ϵ

⇔yn∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) \Leftrightarrow y_n \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)⇔yn​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

Thus, (yn)(y_n)(yn​) also converges to lll.

2.3.5: Let (xn)(x_n)(xn​) and (yn)(y_n)(yn​) be given, and define (zn)(z_n)(zn​) to be the "shuffled" sequence (x1,y1,x2,y2,… )(x_1, y_1, x_2, y_2, \dots)(x1​,y1​,x2​,y2​,…). Prove that (zn)(z_n)(zn​) is convergent if and only if (xn)(x_n)(xn​) and (yn)(y_n)(yn​) are both convergent with lim⁡xn=lim⁡yn=l\lim x_n = \lim y_n = llimxn​=limyn​=l

Proof: (⇐\Leftarrow⇐): We know that lim⁡xn=lim⁡yn=l\lim x_n = \lim y_n = llimxn​=limyn​=l. This means for ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, ∃Nx∈N\exist N_x \in \N∃Nx​∈N s.t. for n≥Nxn \geq N_xn≥Nx​:

Likewise, ∃Ny∈N\exist N_y \in \N∃Ny​∈N s.t. for n≥Nyn \geq N_yn≥Ny​:

yn∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) y_n \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)yn​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

Let M=2max⁡(Nx,Ny)M = 2 \max (N_x, N_y)M=2max(Nx​,Ny​). Then for m≥Mm \geq Mm≥M we have:

m≥2max⁡(Nx,Ny)≥2Nx≥2Nx−1 m \geq 2 \max (N_x, N_y) \geq 2N_x \geq 2N_x - 1m≥2max(Nx​,Ny​)≥2Nx​≥2Nx​−1

⇒m+12≥Nx\Rightarrow \frac{m+1}{2} \geq N_x⇒2m+1​≥Nx​

and

m≥2max⁡(Nx,Ny)≥2Ny m \geq 2 \max (N_x, N_y) \geq 2N_ym≥2max(Nx​,Ny​)≥2Ny​

⇒m2≥Ny\Rightarrow \frac{m}{2} \geq N_y⇒2m​≥Ny​

Thus,

zm={xm+12,if m is oddym2,if m is even}∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)z_m = \left\{\begin{array}{lr} x_{\frac{m + 1}{2}}, & \text{if } m \text{ is odd} \\ y_{\frac{m}{2}}, & \text{if } m \text{ is even} \end{array}\right\} \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)zm​={x2m+1​​,y2m​​,​if m is oddif m is even​}∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

and (zm)→l(z_m) \rightarrow l(zm​)→l.

(⇒\Rightarrow⇒): We know that (zn)(z_n)(zn​) is convergent. Let lim⁡zn=l\lim z_n = llimzn​=l. This means for ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. for n>Nn > Nn>N:

zn∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) z_n \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)zn​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

We also know by definition of (zn)(z_n)(zn​) that:

zn={xn+12,if m is oddyn2,if m is even}z_n = \left\{\begin{array}{lr} x_{\frac{n + 1}{2}}, & \text{if } m \text{ is odd} \\ y_{\frac{n}{2}}, & \text{if } m \text{ is even} \end{array}\right\}zn​={x2n+1​​,y2n​​,​if m is oddif m is even​}

Choose Mx=N+12M_x = \frac{N + 1}{2}Mx​=2N+1​. Note that zN=xMxz_N = x_{M_x}zN​=xMx​​. Note that for m>Mxm > M_xm>Mx​ and m=2n−1m = 2n - 1m=2n−1:

m>Mx⇒2n−1>2N−1⇒n>N m > M_x \Rightarrow 2n - 1 > 2N - 1 \Rightarrow n > N m>Mx​⇒2n−1>2N−1⇒n>N

⇒xm=z2m−1∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) \Rightarrow x_m = z_{2m - 1} \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)⇒xm​=z2m−1​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

Thus, (xm)→l(x_m) \rightarrow l(xm​)→l. Likewise choose My=N2M_y = \frac{N}{2}My​=2N​. Note that for m>Mym > M_ym>My​ and m=2nm = 2nm=2n:

m>My⇒2n>2N⇒n>N m > M_y \Rightarrow 2n > 2N \Rightarrow n > N m>My​⇒2n>2N⇒n>N

⇒ym=z2m∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ) \Rightarrow y_m = z_{2m} \in (l - \epsilon, l + \epsilon)⇒ym​=z2m​∈(l−ϵ,l+ϵ)

Thus, lim⁡xm=lim⁡ym=l\lim x_m = \lim y_m = llimxm​=limym​=l. ■\blacksquare■

2.3.11 (Cesaro Means) Show that if (xn)(x_n)(xn​) is a convergent sequence, then the sequence given by the averages

yn=x1+x2+x3+⋯xnn y_n = \frac{x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \cdots x_n}{n} yn​=nx1​+x2​+x3​+⋯xn​​

also converges to the limit. Give an example to show that is possible for the sequence (yn)(y_n)(yn​) of averages to converge even if (xn)(x_n)(xn​) does not.

Proof: We know that lim⁡xn=l∈R\lim x_n = l \in \Rlimxn​=l∈R. Consider the sequence (yn=x1+x2+x3+⋯xnn)(y_n = \frac{x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \cdots x_n}{n})(yn​=nx1​+x2​+x3​+⋯xn​​). Consider:

∣yn−l∣=∣x1+x2+x3+⋯xnn−l∣=∣x1−ln+x2−ln+⋯+xn−ln∣ |y_n - l| = |\frac{x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \cdots x_n}{n} - l| = |\frac{x_1 - l}{n} + \frac{x_2 - l}{n} + \cdots + \frac{x_n - l}{n}|∣yn​−l∣=∣nx1​+x2​+x3​+⋯xn​​−l∣=∣nx1​−l​+nx2​−l​+⋯+nxn​−l​∣

Consider ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. As (xn)(x_n)(xn​) is a convergent sequence, ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N s.t. for n>Nn > Nn>N

∣xn−l∣<ϵ2(1)\tag{1} |x_n - l| < \frac{\epsilon}{2}∣xn​−l∣<2ϵ​(1)

Now consider ∣yn−l∣|y_n - l|∣yn​−l∣ for n>Nn > Nn>N:

∣yn−l∣=∣x1+x2+x3+⋯xnn−l∣=∣x1+⋯+xN−Nln+xN+1+⋯+xn−(n−N)ln∣ |y_n - l| = |\frac{x_1 + x_2 + x_3 + \cdots x_n}{n} - l| = |\frac{x_1 + \cdots + x_N - Nl}{n} + \frac{x_{N+1} + \cdots + x_n - (n - N)l}{n}|∣yn​−l∣=∣nx1​+x2​+x3​+⋯xn​​−l∣=∣nx1​+⋯+xN​−Nl​+nxN+1​+⋯+xn​−(n−N)l​∣

We know (xn)(x_n)(xn​) is a bounded seqeuence because it converges. Let M≥∣xn∣M \geq |x_n|M≥∣xn​∣ ∀n∈N\forall n \in \N∀n∈N be an upper bound for (xn)(x_n)(xn​). This means

∣yn−l∣=∣x1+⋯+xN−Nln+xN+1+⋯+xn−(n−N)ln∣ |y_n - l| = |\frac{x_1 + \cdots + x_N - Nl}{n} + \frac{x_{N+1} + \cdots + x_n - (n - N)l}{n}|∣yn​−l∣=∣nx1​+⋯+xN​−Nl​+nxN+1​+⋯+xn​−(n−N)l​∣

≤∣NM−Nln+xN+1+⋯+xn−(n−N)ln∣ \leq |\frac{NM - Nl}{n} + \frac{x_{N+1} + \cdots + x_n - (n - N)l}{n}|≤∣nNM−Nl​+nxN+1​+⋯+xn​−(n−N)l​∣

≤∣NM−Nln∣+∣xN+1−ln∣+⋯+∣xn−ln∣ \leq |\frac{NM - Nl}{n}| + |\frac{x_{N+1} - l}{n}| + \cdots + |\frac{x_n - l}{n}|≤∣nNM−Nl​∣+∣nxN+1​−l​∣+⋯+∣nxn​−l​∣

Remember that we chose NNN to be such that for n>Nn > Nn>N xnx_nxn​ is within ϵ2\frac{\epsilon}{2}2ϵ​ of lll (i.e. equation (1)). This further refines our inequality:

∣yn−l∣≤∣NM−Nln∣+∣ϵ2n∣+⋯+∣ϵ2n∣|y_n - l| \leq |\frac{NM - Nl}{n}| + |\frac{\epsilon}{2n}| + \cdots + |\frac{\epsilon}{2n}|∣yn​−l∣≤∣nNM−Nl​∣+∣2nϵ​∣+⋯+∣2nϵ​∣

Noting that ϵ\epsilonϵ is positive, we can drop the absolute values and clean up:

∣yn−l∣≤N∣M−l∣n+(n−N)ϵ2n|y_n - l| \leq N\frac{|M - l|}{n} + \frac{(n - N)\epsilon}{2n}∣yn​−l∣≤Nn∣M−l∣​+2n(n−N)ϵ​

Now we can solve for an nnn s.t. ∣yn−l∣<ϵ|y_n - l| < \epsilon∣yn​−l∣<ϵ:

∣yn−l∣≤N∣M−l∣n+(n−N)ϵ2n<ϵ|y_n - l| \leq N\frac{|M - l|}{n} + \frac{(n - N)\epsilon}{2n} < \epsilon∣yn​−l∣≤Nn∣M−l∣​+2n(n−N)ϵ​<ϵ

⇒2N∣M−l∣+nϵ−Nϵ<2nϵ\Rightarrow 2N|M - l| + n\epsilon - N\epsilon < 2n\epsilon⇒2N∣M−l∣+nϵ−Nϵ<2nϵ

⇒2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ<2nϵ−nϵ\Rightarrow 2N|M - l| - N\epsilon < 2n\epsilon - n\epsilon⇒2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ<2nϵ−nϵ

⇒2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ<nϵ\Rightarrow 2N|M - l| - N\epsilon < n\epsilon⇒2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ<nϵ

⇒2N∣M−l∣−Nϵϵ<n\Rightarrow \frac{2N|M - l| - N\epsilon}{\epsilon} < n⇒ϵ2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ​<n

As ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0, the term on the left of the inequality is always defined. Thus if we chooose N′>2N∣M−l∣−NϵϵN' > \frac{2N|M - l| - N\epsilon}{\epsilon}N′>ϵ2N∣M−l∣−Nϵ​ then

∣yn−l∣<ϵ|y_n - l| < \epsilon∣yn​−l∣<ϵ

■\blacksquare■

2.4 The Monotone Convergence Theorem and a First Look at the Infinite Series

Definition 2.4.1: A sequence (an)(a_n)(an​) is increasing if an≤an+1a_n \leq a_{n+1}an​≤an+1​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N and decreasing if an≥an+1a_n \geq a_{n+1}an​≥an+1​ for all n∈Nn \in \Nn∈N. A sequence is monotone if it is either increasing or decreasing.

Theorem 2.4.2 (Monotone Convergence Theorem): If a sequence is monotone and bounded, then it converges.

Proof: Let (an)(a_n)(an​) be a monotone and bounded sequence.

  1. (an)(a_n)(an​) is increasing: By the Axiom of Completeness and given that (an)(a_n)(an​) is bounded, choose sup⁡m∈Nam\sup_{m \in \N} a_msupm∈N​am​ as the least upper bound of (an)(a_n)(an​). Let ϵ>0\epsilon > 0ϵ>0. Consider

∣an−sup⁡m∈Nam∣<ϵ(1)\tag{1} | a_n - \sup_{m \in \N} a_m | < \epsilon∣an​−m∈Nsup​am​∣<ϵ(1)

Note that ∃n∈N\exist n \in \N∃n∈N such that (1) is true since if none existed, then sup⁡m∈Nam−ϵ<sup⁡m∈Nam\sup_{m \in \N} a_m - \epsilon < \sup_{m \in \N} a_msupm∈N​am​−ϵ<supm∈N​am​ would be a smaller upper bound. Next, note that given N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that (1) is true, (1) is also true for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N as an≥aNa_n \geq a_Nan​≥aN​ ((an)(a_n)(an​) is increasing). Thus ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0 ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N such that for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, ∣an−sup⁡m∈Nam∣<ϵ| a_n - \sup_{m \in \N} a_m | < \epsilon∣an​−supm∈N​am​∣<ϵ. Therefore, (an)(a_n)(an​) converges to $ \sup_{m \in \N} a_m$.

  1. (an)(a_n)(an​) is decreasing: By the definition of bounded sequence, an∈[−M,M]a_n \in [-M, M]an​∈[−M,M] ∀n∈N\forall n \in \N∀n∈N. Thus, by the Axiom of Completeness, inf⁡m∈Nam\inf_{m \in \N} a_minfm∈N​am​ exists. Consider

∣an−inf⁡m∈Nam∣<ϵ(2)\tag{2} | a_n - \inf_{m \in \N} a_m | < \epsilon∣an​−m∈Ninf​am​∣<ϵ(2)

Note that ∃n∈N\exist n \in \N∃n∈N such that (2) is true since if none existed, then inf⁡m∈Nam+ϵ>inf⁡m∈Nam\inf_{m \in \N} a_m + \epsilon > \inf_{m \in \N} a_minfm∈N​am​+ϵ>infm∈N​am​ would be a larger lower bound. Next, note that given N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that (2) is true, (2) is also true for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N as an≤aNa_n \leq a_Nan​≤aN​ ((an)(a_n)(an​) is decreasing). Thus ∀ϵ>0\forall \epsilon > 0∀ϵ>0 ∃N∈N\exist N \in \N∃N∈N such that for n≥Nn \geq Nn≥N, ∣an−inf⁡m∈Nam∣<ϵ| a_n - \inf_{m \in \N} a_m | < \epsilon∣an​−infm∈N​am​∣<ϵ. Therefore, (an)(a_n)(an​) converges to $ \inf_{m \in \N} a_m$. ■\blacksquare■

Definition 2.4.3: Let (bn)(b_n)(bn​) be a sequence. An infinite series is a formal expression of the form

∑n=1∞bn=b1+b2+b3+⋯ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty} b_n = b_1 + b_2 + b_3 + \cdotsn=1∑∞​bn​=b1​+b2​+b3​+⋯
